chapters.name: Choosing and Evaluating Robotic Platforms
topics: What criteria should guide the choice between platforms like Boston Dynamics Spot and alternative robotic bases for guide work?
How do payload capacity, size, and form factor affect the usability of a robotic guide dog in crowded urban environments?
In what ways do terrain requirements, climate, and regional infrastructure shape platform selection decisions?
How should teams weigh commercial off-the-shelf solutions against custom-designed robots for this application?

chapters.name: Mobility, Stability, and Terrain Handling
topics: What types of locomotion and gait patterns are most suitable for safely guiding a blind user across varied terrain?
How can engineers evaluate stability, balance, and fall recovery in real-world conditions like curbs, stairs, and uneven sidewalks?
Which design trade-offs arise between agility, speed, and safety when tuning the robot's motion behaviors?
How can simulation and physical testing be combined to validate mobility performance before deployment with users?

chapters.name: Power, Reliability, and Environmental Constraints
topics: How should battery life and charging strategies be designed around the daily routines of blind and visually impaired users?
What environmental conditions (rain, snow, heat, dust) must robotic guide dogs withstand, and how do these shape hardware design?
How can teams model reliability and mean time between failure for a robotic guide dog operating in a city for years?
What redundancies in hardware and power systems are necessary to avoid leaving a user stranded mid-journey?
